About The Maine Coon


  • Origin
  • Appearance
  • Personality
  • Health
  • Nutrition And feeding
  • Fur Care
  • Child Friendliness

Origin

Country Of Origin: America

The predecessors of the Maine coon were long-haired cats that sailors brought to American Maine in the 1850s. These cats mated with the local short-haired cats. The offspring were large, robust cats with semi-long fur and bushy tails reminiscent of a raccoon's tail, hence the name maine coon (raccoon is called "raccoon" in English). The cats developed thick, heavy fur to withstand the extreme cold of Maine's winters. Special Maine Coon shows were held as early as the 1860s and the breed became a very popular pet. The Maine coon was imported to the UK in the 1980s.

Appearance

The Maine Coon is the largest of all cat breeds and has a muscular body and sturdy legs. The head has a square muzzle and large ears, which are wide at the base and set high. The long and thick coat consists of underwool covered by glossy, waterproof overcoat. The fur is shorter on the head, neck and shoulders and longer on the back, sides and tail. On the belly and hind legs, the fur is thick and shaggy. The neck collar is stronger in males than in females. The tail is long and bushy and the ears have tufts on the tip. The fur on the paws has a "snowshoe" effect. Maine coons come in thirty or more colors. The eyes can be green, gold or copper colored; white cats may have blue or different colored eyes.

Personality

Maine Coons have a pleasant disposition / temper and are very playful and friendly. They enjoy human company and make excellent pets. Perhaps their simple origins are the reason why you often find them huddled together in all sorts of places. They enjoy being outdoors and should have the opportunity to climb and play hunter. The main coon is known for its cooing soft voice.

Health

The Maine Coon appears to have a high risk of suffering from the heart disease hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. In addition, the breed often suffers from hip dysplasia. Ask the breeder about these conditions before buying a cat.

Nutrition And Feeding

Each cat is unique and has its own taste in food. However, cats are carnivores and each cat must obtain 41 different and specific nutrients from its food. The distribution of these nutrients varies according to age, lifestyle and general health so it is not surprising that a growing, energetic kitten needs a different balance of nutrients in its diet than a less active, older cat. Other things to consider are feeding the right amount of food to maintain an ideal body weight in accordance with feeding guides and taking into account individual preferences for wet or dry food.

Fur Care

A Maine Coon takes good care of its long coat, but needs regular grooming to stay in good condition. Like all other cats, this breed needs regular vaccinations and parasite checks.

Child friendliness

This breed normally gets along great with children, but each cat has its own personality based on training and life experience. Talk to the cattery, if you are adopting, for more information about a specific cat's personality.
